Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CyberSEES: Type 1: A Pilot Study on Cognitive Acoustic Underwater Networks (CAUNet) for Sustainable Ocean Monitoring and Exploration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Environmental awareness is a key to sustainable ocean monitoring and exploration. To meet the ever growing requirements of the ocean monitoring and exploration applications, and to preserve a sustainable blue ocean for next generations, a cognitive acoustic underwater network (CAUNet) that is aware of the coexistence of multiple underwater acoustic systems will be designed. The project goals include investigating acoustic spectrum usage via data collection and analysis, designing algorithms, software and hardware for acoustic spectrum sensing and spectrum management, and evaluating the feasibility and performance of the proposed work via simulations, and lab and field experiments.

This project will make significant contributions to the underwater network research community by improving the efficiency of UANs while making them more environmentally friendly. The research activities in this project also provide a rich environment and platform that can facilitate educating and training students from high school to graduate level and inspire students in underrepresented groups to pursue research in science and engineering. Moreover, this project will motivate and enable a wide range of research and outreach activities within the underwater communications, networking, engineering, and marine science communities, and promote progress towards practical solutions in diverse aquatic applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The earth is a blue planet. Over 70% of it is covered by the ocean. The sheer quantity of marine lives it contains far exceeds those ever habitat the land. The vast yet largely unexplored ocean has not only fascinated generations of human beings by providing seemly endless resourcesbut also poses challenges as how to explore and exploit the ocean in sustainable ways.

Underwater Acoustic Networks (UANs) has emerged as a promising technique that canfacilitate a wide range of aquatic applications, such as scientific exploration, commercialexploitation and coastline protection. Existing work usually assumes that the network takesfull control over the designated frequency band(s). However, in real applications, multiple acousticsystems, including UANs, acoustic telemetry instruments and marine lives, may co-exist andaffect the performance of each other. Moreover, there are growing concerns about the effectof man-made noise (from UANs, oil drilling, sonar systems, etc.) on marine animals. In short, environmental awareness is the key to sustainable ocean monitoring and exploration. How tosolve these issues is the subject of this proposal.

To meet the ever growing requirements of the ocean monitoring and exploration applications, and to preserve a sustainable blue ocean for next generations, in this project, we designed a cognitive acoustic underwater network (CAUNet) that can be aware of the coexistenceof multiple underwater acoustic systems. We identified and tackled several fundamental issues, including acoustic spectrum sensing, management, and usage, as summarized below.1) Acoustic spectrum usage: A CAUNet can never be truly environmental aware without knowingthe real environment. In this project, we empirically evaluated the acoustic spectrum usage by conducting an environmental assessment in Long Island Sound, Connecticut. 2) Acoustic spectrum sensing: For a CAUNet to be environment-aware, a key problem is to designhigh-performance spectrum sensing devices and algorithms. Based on some real sea test datacollected in the past, we proposed a novel hybrid spectrum sensing approach to improve performancein terms of accuracy and reliability. 3) Acoustic spectrum management: In UANs, a large portion of the acoustic spectrum is oftenused sporadically. In order to improve spectrum efficiency, we proposed a sender initiatednegotiation based MAC protocol to enable interference avoidance and seamless acoustic communications.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this project lies in its fundamental research to the sustainabilityin ocean monitoring and exploration with CAUNets. Our efforts in this project involve investigatingacoustic spectrum usage via data collection and analysis, designing algorithms, software, and hardware for acoustic spectrum sensing and spectrum management, and evaluating the feasibilityand performance of the proposed work via simulations, and lab and field experiments. At the end of this project, a set of algorithms and protocols for CAUNets were delivered.

Broader Impacts :The broader impacts of this project include: (1) Research impacts: this project made contributions to the underwater network research community by improving the efficiencyof UANs while making them more environmental friendly; (2) Education impacts: the researchactivities in this project provides a rich environment and platform that facilitated educating and training students from female and underrepresentedgroups; (3) Societal impacts: this project will motivate and enable a wide range of researchand outreach activities within the underwater communications, networking, engineering, andmarine science community, and promote unprecedented progress towards practical solutions indiverse aquatic applications.
